title: ISSS608
text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications. This website is for Jeremy Junpeng Liu’s coursework.

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read.csv("data/Exam_data_new.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text: exam_data <- read.csv("data/Exam_data_new.csv")

title: About
text: Hi there! thank you for visiting my page. This is Jeremy Junpeng Liu where l detail my journey through  Visual Analytics and Applications as part of my Master of IT in Business programme at Singapore Management University. I hope your journey is as fulfilling as mine! Special thanks to Prof. Kam Tin seong for his dedication, patience, and generosity in sharing his knowledge.

title: In-Class_ex01
text: Nothing has been assigned yet ;D

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
ggplot

# echo: false
ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
R Graphics

hist(exam_data$MATHS)









Why ggplot2 is recommended?
Personally, I believe that ggplot2 allows furthur adjustments meaning we can customize the chart better.

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.1 Geometric Objects: geom_bar

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.2 Geometric Objects: geom_dotplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) + geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.3 Geometric Objects: geom_histogram()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()       

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.7.4 Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()
text:
1.7.4 Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.7.5 Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()
text:
1.7.5 Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.6 Geometric Objects: geom-density()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density()           









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.7 Geometric Objects: geom_boxplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()            









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.8 Geometric Objects: geom_violin

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.9 Geometric Objects: geom_point()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.7.10 geom objects can be combined

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.8.1 Working with stat()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.8.2 Working with stat - the stat_summary() method
text:
1.8.2 Working with stat - the stat_summary() method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.8.3 Working with stat - the geom() method
text:
1.8.3 Working with stat - the geom() method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.8.4 Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?
text:
1.8.4 Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size=0.5)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.9.1 Working with facet_wrap()
facet_wrap wraps a 1d sequence of panels into 2d. This is generally a better use of screen space than facet_grid because most displays are roughly rectangular.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.9.2 facet_grid() function
facet_grid() forms a matrix of panels defined by row and column facetting variables. It is most useful when you have two discrete variables, and all combinations of the variables exist in the data.
The code chunk below plots a trellis plot using facet_grid().

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.10.1 Working with Coordinate

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
section: 1.10.2 Changing the y- and x-axis range
text:
1.10.2 Changing the y- and x-axis range

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 01
text:
1.11.1 Working with theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()
